table_items.text: PERIPHERALLY INSERTED CENTRAL CATHETER (PICC) AND MID LINE MANAGEMENT AND TROUBLESHOOTING POLICY

data.text: Contents
Experienced support for advice for maintenance and troubleshooting ......................... 8
PiCC/midline dressing change and patency maintenance ............................................ 9

Appendix 7: Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter (PiCC) and Midline (Long Peripheral Venous Catheter) Sepsis Protocol ..................................................................................... 26
Appendix 8: Total Implanted Vascular Access Device (TIVAD) – (Portacath) ................... 28

Appendix 9: Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter (PiCC) related Deep Vein Thrombus (DVT) Treatment Algorithm ................................................................................................ 29

Appendix 10: Patient or staff raise concern of PiCC related DVT ...................................... 30 Appendix 11: Competency for the Management of Central Venous Access Device (CVAD) 32 Appendix 12: PICC damage .............................................................................................. 35 Appendix 13: Preliminary Equality Analysis ....................................................................... 35
Introduction

PiCC and Mid-Lines are short to mid-term central and peripheral venous catheters which are used when patients require prolonged (greater than 10 days) intravenous (IV) access in accordance with UK Vessel Health and Preservation guidelines (2021) Epic3 guidelines (2014): IVAD9 e.g. PiCC's for Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN), antibiotics (in particular those with a pH less than 5 or greater than 9 that are vesicant or irritant), blood products, fluids and chemotherapy or blood sampling. Mid-Lines tend to be used for non-irritant or non-vesicant antibiotics or fluids.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
This guideline applies to the management of PiCC and Mid-Lines in adult patients.
All clinical staff involved in the ongoing management of PiCC and Mid-Lines must adhere to the principles described in this Policy.
Definitions

table_items.text: 1 Peripherally inserted Central Catheter (PiCC) A PiCC (Peripherally inserted Central Catheter) is a long, slender, flexible tube inserted into a peripheral vein (typically the upper arm is the area of choice) and advanced until the tip is sited in the lower third of the Superior Vena Cava ideally at the cavo-atrial junction. Typically they are 40-50 cm in length. May have single or double lumen Inserted under direct ultrasound guidance (NICE (2012) recommendation ) Placement is confirmed with CXR or ECG Tip Position device. Can remain in situ for up to 14 months or more without complications, ideally 6months and replaced by a long term CVAD (central venous access device) if required.

2 Mid-Line This is a peripheral venous access device: longer than peripheral “cannula” but shorter than a PiCC line. Typically they are 8-25cm length. They are also sited in an upper arm vein but tip ends below the level of the axillary line. Routinely used for 1- 8 weeks or length of treatment if there are no complications As line does not reach a central vein position does not need to verified by X-Ray or ECG tip positioning device Permits the infusion of most/all infusates that are appropriate for peripheral use without the need for renewal of cannula every 72 hrs Some medications cannot be administered via a mid-line as mentioned previously stated please check with PiCC team or MEDUSA online injectable medicines guide.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Medicines Committees have responsibility to advise

Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the trust has the necessary management systems in place to enable the effective implementation of this policy and overall responsibility for the health and safety of staff, patients and visitors.

Director of Nursing has strategic responsibility for ensuring that the correct systems are in place to facilitate the awareness of nursing staff of this policy and that appropriate support is given to enable staff to deliver practice and comply with it and that appropriate action is taken when expectations within this document are not complied with.

Matrons are responsible and accountable for providing reassurance that staff within their clinical areas are aware of this policy and comply with it. It is their responsibility to escalate where expectations within this document are not complied with and ensure relevant action is taken.

Ward Senior Sisters are responsible and accountable for ensuring that staff within their clinical areas are aware of this policy and comply with it. It is their responsibility to escalate where expectations within this document are not complied with and ensure relevant action is taken. To ensure all of the registered nurses within their jurisdiction are up to date and competent in the CVC and PICC competencies prior to accessing or maintain these lines.

Medical Director has strategic responsibility to ensure that systems are in place to facilitate the awareness of medical staff of this policy and that appropriate support is given to enable staff to deliver practice and comply with it. It is also imperative that appropriate action is taken when this policy is not complied with and this is escalated.

Clinical/Educational Supervisors should ensure that foundation doctors and also those more senior that have no experience with these lines comply with this policy in the accessing and the ongoing maintenance and subsequent removal of PiCC and Mid-lines to prevent complications/ patient harm and/or premature removal. All registered nurses should also adhere to the above until such time that there are trust-wide competencies and DOPS and enough trained competent senior staff following to assess competence. Refer to the Royal Marsden Online for standards of care for these lines. https://www.rmmonline.co.uk/search?dc_type=andq=picc

All clinical staff must comply with this policy; have a responsibility to ensure that the accessing, care and management of these lines is in accordance with this policy ensuring all infection prevention measures are also adhered too and is embedded into their everyday practice and applied consistently at all times in line with the Vessel Health Preservation guidelines 2021.

The decision to commence troubleshooting for the listed instances in section 11.0 should only occur by a qualified doctor who can demonstrate their competence in accessing Central Lines and/or peripheral IV devices or a Registered Nurse with completed IV Therapy, CVC competencies, and have relevant experience with PICC or midlines. (Section 8.0) (Please note this may be generic to certain specialities e.g. anaesthesia and Intensive Care Medicine trainees) The doctor/registered nurse should have received teaching about PiCC and Midlines via their induction day, IV Therapy day or from a qualified member of the PiCC Service and be able to evidence this.
The PICC and Vascular Access Registered Nurses will:

Make the informed decision to insert and perform the actual insertion of a PiCC or Mid-line for the purpose of the above indications following appropriate referral and assessment along with patients' informed consent must be made by the PiCC Service Trained Inserter only, taking into consideration the risks and benefits to each individual patient. This decision to insert should only be made following a comprehensive assessment of any potential relative or absolute contraindications, risks and benefits to the patient with the patient. In complex cases the Lead Consultant Nurse will aid this decision making process in accordance with the VHP and INS guidelines and evidence based practice. This decision should be documented by the PiCC and VA Team in the medical notes signed, dated and timed or EPR system.
Only qualified members of the PiCC service with the relevant skills and expertise can insert a PiCC or Mid-line and subsequently confirming its correct position.
The PICC and VA team will ensure all outpatients (especially chemotherapy patients have had COVID swab prior to procedure in accordance with current government and trust guidance.
Consent

Informed verbal consent must be sought prior to any maintenance and troubleshooting of a PiCC or Mid-Line. A clear explanation of the procedure should be given and verbal consent gained if the patient is unable to respond verbally, other means of communication should be sought. If the patient is unable to communicate or lacks mental capacity, staff should refer to the Trust's Consent Policy and Mental Capacity Act Policy. An MCA2 form should be completed in full and a copy submitted to the adult safeguarding team as per trust policy.
Experienced support for advice for maintenance and troubleshooting

During PiCC Service Hours the Team should always be contacted (via switchboard or pager #65551403 for support and advice with any of the following issues: Mechanical Phlebitis, Difficult/Sluggish Withdrawal, Withdrawal Occlusion, Complete Line Occlusion, Line Malposition, Insertion Site Infection, Pain upon flushing, Difficult Removal - See Appendix 1 Troubleshooting Guide
There is no out of hour's service.

If there is not sufficient experienced support available for you to deal with the issue or to safely continue using the line (for example at night) and you are not competent to follow the troubleshooting guidelines, unless clinically urgent you should refrain from using the line, delay any further troubleshooting and gain other Intravenous access where possible until the support is available. See the IV escalation policy for guidance on who to call for difficult IV access patients
The rationale for any decisions made should be recorded in the patient's medical notes.

DO NOT REMOVE the line unless absolutely clinically indicated (High probability of line sepsis with no other source of sepsis or severe pain due to phlebitis) and all other avenues explored as it may not be possible to replace.(See algorithm for suspected line sepsis below in appendix 1)
Equipment for care and maintenance
Plastic apron and gloves (additional PPE as per trust and government guidance for COVID where/when required)
Cleaned Dressing Trolley/IV tray or alcohol cleaned surface
Sterile Dressing Pack
Clear occlusive dressing Tegaderm (unimpregnated) or equivalent dressing if skin is fragile.
Chloroprep 2% 1.5ml applicator or ‘Sanicloth' 2% or chlorhexidine soaked gauze

New “Statlock” securement device where required (PiCC and Vascular Access Team nurses will provide these on request although these should be ordered through NHS supplies and central point on Feering, Heybridge and Billericay wards stock also)
‘BIOPATCH' chlorhexidine patch supplied by PiCC Service or from central point of storage
20ml syringe
2 plastic vials of Sterile 0.9% (Nacl) Normal Saline
New needle free access obturator Braun ‘Caresite'
PiCC/midline dressing change and patency maintenance
Most complications occur from wet dressings therefore check dressing and insertion site through dressing daily and record VIP on vital pac.
Perform dressing change WEEKLY or earlier if the dressing is peeling/lifting away or excessive amount of moisture is noticed underneath.
Dressing procedure:
Position and support with a pillow the patient's arm at 90' angle to body for clear access to line site
Put plastic apron on and wash/ cleanse hands thoroughly
Open dressing pack onto clean surface and open other stock onto sterile field

Don unsterile gloves to remove old dressing: anchor lumen(s) with one hand to secure the catheter whilst removing dressing and remove old dressing from the bottom of arm towards top minimises inadvertently pulling catheter out of skin
Remove gloves; cleanse hands with alcohol gel and put on sterile gloves

If orange 'Securacath' securement device is not in use - Apply long thin securing strip from ‘statlock' pack over PiCC/Midline close to insertion site to prevent accidental migration of the PiCC/Midline
Remove Statlock/adhesive securement device from skin holding the PICC/midline at all times. DO NOT PULL ON THE PICC (alcohol required to remove)
Use sterile gauze to hold catheter/ lumens in place whilst cleansing skin
Use 2% Chloraprep applicator or equivalent sani-cloth to clean skin-catheter junction using away motion from site
Check measurement of catheter against recorded measurement to ensure no migration has occurred. DO NOT ADVANCE CATHETER IF MIGRATION NOTED
Thoroughly clean surrounding skin that will be covered with the dressing using back-forward and side-to-side motions for at least 30seconds
Allow chlorhexidine to air dry. DO NOT pat dry with gauze
Only apply gauze pressure dressing if site is bleeding
Position new Statlock/adhesive securement device in position and apply new ‘BIOPATCH' blue side up with the slit facing towards the bottom of the dressing. DO NOT PULL ON THE PICC/midline

Apply transparent occlusive dressing and label with date and secure with a bandage or ‘Comfifast' if required. NB: The bandage or ‘Comfiifast' must not be tight as it may lead to poor flow and thrombus formation. ‘Tubigrip' should NOT be used for it is too tight and encourages thrombus formation.

Attach a 20ml normal saline 0.9% filled syringe and then the line should then be aspirated if a PiCC to ensure blood flash back and accurate tip position, followed by brisk ‘Push-pause' flushing technique as per protocol. 10mls instilled into each lumen in the same manner to ensure patency. Please note Midlines do not and will not aspirate for they are the same as a cannula and therefore it is not part of the protocol. Please see flushing protocol for the lines.
Discard used equipment/old dressing in clinical waste bag
Record dressing and findings in patient's notes and report any untoward findings to PICC and VA team
The ‘Limbo' waterproof arm protector supplied by the PiCC team at insertion should always be used when bathing or showering. The line/dressing should NEVER GET WET.

If orange ‘Securacath' device in use, see video within PICC and Vascular Access Videoson intranet for information if unsure. Care is exactly the same except the device does not require changing it remains in situ for the whole indwell time of the line and can be lifted up gently to clean 360 around. DO NOT change the angle of the ‘securacath' Observe closely for kinking of line below' securacath' and use ‘steristrips' to prevent this if necessary.
PiCC/midline flushing and line handling
PiCC and Midlines must be handled with Surgical Approach Aseptic Technique as per Trust Policy for CVC's utilizing the drapes within the dressing pack:
Wash/ cleanse hands thoroughly as per IP Trust Protocol and apply apron( and any other PPE required due to COVID or other infection status)
Clean work surface with Sani-cloth/alcohol and open dressing pack/ all other sterile equipment onto sterile field
Cleanse hands with alcohol gel, put on sterile gloves and place sterile towel under line
Wipe NFIVAD surface well and allow to air dry on sterile surface then prime with Nacl 0.9%.

Ensuring clamp is in place with midlines (NB: PiCC has an integral pressure activated valve at the hub and subsequently no clamp); thoroughly wipe around obturator/NFIVAD with ‘Sanicloth', remove and discard; with ‘Sanicloth clean around hub of lumen(s) and allow to air dry

Attach a 20ml normal saline 0.9% filled syringe and then the line should then be aspirated if a PICC to ensure blood flash back and accurate tip position, followed by brisk ‘Push-pause' flushing technique. 10mls instilled into each lumen in the same manner to ensure patency. Please note Midlines do not and will not aspirate for they are the same as a cannula and therefore it is not part of the protocol
Remove the syringe once patency is confirmed and clean hub with sanicloth
Attach infusion line or withdraw blood sample (discarding 5mls initially to avoid sample contamination)
Once procedure/treatment is finished perform flushing as per protocol immediately to prevent line blockage/occlusion

Please note that evidence base has now demonstrated that PiCC and Midlines do not require to be ‘Heparin Locked' Regular 0.9% Normal Saline 20 ml flushing is adequate to maintain patency. This should be performed every  hours or minimum once weekly in the community if there are no clotting issues with the patient which may incur an increased risk of blockage. Please seek advice from the PiCC and VA Service if unsure
Only use a 20ml syringe when accessing/flushing a PiCC/Midline for a smaller syringe could lead to rupture of the line
Removal of PICC and midlines
Remove Line only on doctor's orders and following clarification from PiCC and VA team: Any Registered Nurse or Doctor can remove a PiCC or Midline.
Clean hands: wash/alcohol gel and apply non-sterile gloves( and any extra PPE required due to COVID or other infection status)
Lay patient flat and support arm with a pillow out at 90 degrees

Remove dressing and adhesive catheter securement device (if orange ‘Securacath' in situ remove line first. See removal video on PiCC service Clinical Pages section prior to removal. DO NOT JUST PULL OR CUT SKIN TO REMOVE)
Clean site with Chlorhexidine 2% (Chloraprep applicator or Sanicloth) and allow to air dry before removing device
Apply gentle traction on catheter, holding the catheter near the skin
As catheter comes out, keep moving your hand forward on the catheter so traction is applied from close to the skin (possibility of catheter breaking if traction applied too far from site)
If resistance is felt stop removal. Apply warm compresses for 20-30 minutes.
If still resistance- leave line in-situ and call PICC and VA Team for advice - no harm can be used by leaving line as it is, if covered.
Place sterile gauze over site and apply digital pressure until any bleeding stops
Cover site with gauze and transparent dressing to be kept dry for 48hours
Change dressing daily until site epithelialized
If removal difficult see section 11.9 Difficult removal
Troubleshooting
Mechanical phlebitis

Mechanical phlebitis occurs when movement of a foreign body against a vein wall causes inflammation of the vein (phlebitis). This is a frequent complication of a PiCC or a Midline and is normally evident within 10 days of insertion. Symptoms and signs present around the biceps region above the PiCC/Midline insertion site. As the line travels more proximally, the vein increases in size with less contact between the vessel wall and catheter, thus minimising the spread of phlebitis.
Symptoms and signs include:
Redness
Swelling
Pain
Skin warm to touch
Venous cord (hard palpable vein tracking proximally)

The above symptoms can be confused with insertion site infection, cellulitis and thrombosis. Following the appropriate flow charts to exclude these conditions may prevent premature PiCC/Mid line removal. (See Troubleshooting Management Flow chart 1 in the appendix) The following symptoms and signs may help to exclude other complications:
Is the catheter difficult to flush?
Can blood be withdrawn from the catheter?
Is the arm swollen or discoloured?
Does the lower forearm have engorged veins compared to other limb without line in situ
Is there pain in the shoulder, axilla or neck?
Is the patient pyrexial with other signs suggestive of infection?
Is the exit site inflamed, red with exudate present?

Once a diagnosis of mechanical phlebitis has been made regular observation and assessment is required. Treatment will depend on the severity of symptoms and may include warm compresses and NSAID's. If symptoms do not improve then PiCC/Midline removal should be considered after discussion with PICC and VA Team
Withdrawal occlusion

Withdrawal occlusion (WO) can be defined as the inability to withdraw blood via the PiCC/Midline but it retains a capacity to infuse solutions without difficulty. The significance of WO is that the practitioner cannot be certain that the catheter is in the vein when there is no free flowing blood return. This is a standard check procedure prior to infusion via a centrally placed catheter as leakage of vesicant or irritant drugs/solutions into surrounding tissues can cause an extravasation injury. Malposition into surrounding tissues is very rarely seen with PiCC lines. WO is more commonly due to thrombotic or non-thrombotic causes:
Non-thrombotic:
Catheter tip resting against vein wall
Catheter malfunction (i.e. faulty valve)
Internal catheter fracture
Malposition Thrombotic:
Fibrin sheath
Fibrin tail
Mural thrombus
Catheter related DVT
Thrombolytic agents

Thrombolytic agents are a group of drugs which work by breaking down blood clots (clot lysis). Alteplase is the most commonly used thrombolytic agent in catheter care. A bolus dose of Alteplase may help to break down the fibrin formation at the catheter tip therefore preventing WO. The recommended dose of Alteplase is for use as a bolus lock for catheter clearance is 2mg. This must be prescribed by a Doctor or under the PGD by the PiCC Service Registered Nurses and those added to the PGD.

Saline Challenge Flushing the catheter with 20-50ml of saline can be used to demonstrate the presence or absence of extravasation. Close observation of the patient is required. This may allow continued use of the catheter if position can be confirmed (CXR/lineogram) but will not rule out a fibrin sheath. Therefore a saline challenge has limited, short term uses. (See Troubleshooting Management Flow Chart 2 in the appendix)
Complete catheter/line occlusion complete

Catheter occlusion (CCO) is where there is an inability to infuse solutions together with an inability to aspirate blood from the catheter. CCO can result from a thrombotic or a non-thrombotic cause. The most common non-thrombotic causes are:
Mechanical obstruction
Drug or mineral precipitates
Lipid residue

A thrombotic complete occlusion develops as a result of blood within the catheter (usually due to a failure to flush the catheter following blood sampling). (See troubleshooting management Flowchart 3 in Appendix)
Once a decision has been made that thrombus is the likely cause of complete occlusion, administration of a bolus dose of Alteplase is required. Licensed for PiCC's and renal CVC's only.
11.3.1 Equipment

Small dressing pack, sterile gloves 2 x 10ml syringes, Green needle, Sharps bin, 3 way tap Alteplase (Actilyse) 2mg available in SDEC/CDU/ Day therapies, 2.2 ml Water for Injections Sterile chlorhexidine 2% wipe, NFIVAD.
Explain procedure to patient, wash hands and prepare equipment in accordance with trust policy.
Check Alteplase ampoule according to Trust policy.
Open dressing pack, syringes, sterile chlorhexidine wipe and 3 way tap onto the sterile field. Place Alteplase and Water for Injections ampoules at edge of sterile field.

Wash hands again or use alcohol hand rub. Don sterile gloves. Using a sterile swab to hold the ampoule, draw up 2 mls of water into a syringe. Repeat the process with the Alteplase ampoule wiping the rubber bung top with the chlorhexidine wipe and allowing it to dry.

Reconstitute Alteplase 2mg with the 2.2mls Water for Injections (each vial has 2.2mg inclusing a 10% overfill.). Now 1mg/1ml. Draw up/transfer 2 ml of the solution into a  ml syringe to avoid increase pressure.
Prime the 3 way tap with the alteplase solution. With a sterile swab remove the NFIVAD from the PiCC and attach the 3-way tap to the end of the line. Close the 3-way tap to the patient.
Attach the syringe containing Alteplase to one access point of the 3-way tap and one empty syringe to the other access point.

Turn tap to "closed position" to Alteplase and "open position" to empty syringe. Pull back on empty syringe to 5ml marker to create a vacuum within the catheter. Whilst maintaining traction, turn tap to "closed position" to empty syringe and 12 "open position" to Alteplase. A small amount of Alteplase will be drawn into the vacuum within the catheter. Remove empty syringe and expel air from the syringe.
Repeat every 2 minutes till all the Alteplase is within the line. This can take 20 minutes to complete.
Attach new NFIVAD to end of line and leave Alteplase in-situ for 1-2 hours.

Attempt to withdraw blood. If blood withdrawal is possible, flush catheter with 15- 20 mls saline according to protocol. If blood withdrawal is not possible then you may repeat the injection of bolus Alteplase. If the second attempt is not successful. Discuss with PiCC and VA Team. Possibly Mechanical cause.
Torn/split lines

PiCC/Mid lines are made of soft, pliable polyurethane. Although designed to be durable, tears, pinholes or leaks can occur with time or with improper handling. Tears and splits can occur anywhere along the length of the line. However, are more common close to the exit site or in the external part of the line. Signs may include:
Leakage from the line when flushing
Unexplained fluid under the dressing or along the external part of the catheter
11.4.1 Management:

Flush catheter with Normal Saline to help identify the leak point. If leak confirmed use alternative i.v access and refer patient for either exchange of PiCC over wire or removal +\- re-siting of PiCC/Midline. This decision will depend on catheter age, location, infection status and duration of required therapy. Please discuss with PICC and VA team.
A lineogram/venogram can be booked with Interventional Radiology to confirm patency of a line.
Line associated deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
(Refer to DVT treatment algorithm; Appendix 9 and10)
The incidence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) associated with a PiCC is approximately 5-20% on USS imaging. This includes non-symptomatic (silent) DVT, the management of which is controversial.
Risk factors include: small vessel size, larger diameter catheters, phlebitis and pro- thrombotic tendency i.e. cancer. (See Troubleshooting Management Flow chart in Appendix).

Management of clinically symptomatic DVT (confirmed by radiological imaging preferably a Duplex Scan) will depend on the severity of the symptoms and the ongoing need to maintain continuous intravenous (i.v) access. PiCC's can remain in use if the patient receives treatment for the thrombus and becomes asymptomatic until their requirement for this access is negated. Consideration should be given to finding alternative i.v access where possible if the picc has to be removed and the risk of thrombotic emboli on removal of the PiCC. Ideally patients should be fully anti-coagulated for 48-72 hours prior to catheter removal. Removal should take place in a suitable area with access to monitoring; oxygen therapy and medical assistance should respiratory/cardiovascular instability due to potential pulmonary embolus and under the advice of the patient's clinician. Patients will need to be referred to a Physician for on-going management of anticoagulation for the thrombus which may be required for 3-6 months in line with trust policy.
PiCC tip malposition

The optimal position for the tip of a PiCC is in the lower third of the SVC at the cavoatrial junction. When the tip of a PiCC moves from the desired position it is referred to as Catheter Tip Malposition. It is important to note that malposition of a PiCC can be symptom free.
Symptoms which may require further investigation include:
Sensation in the neck during flushing- "ear gurgling"
Chest pain
Difficulty aspirating blood
Difficulty/inability to infuse fluids
Visible reflux of blood into the catheter
More commonly, migration of the external portion of the PiCC at the insertion site. (See Troubleshooting Management Flow Chart in Appendix)

If there is a suggestion of malposition then a chest X-ray should be performed to confirm tip position and use of line paused. Action required will depend on where the tip lies and what drugs are being infused through the catheter. It is possible the catheter can be used as a midline if the drugs are not vesicant to the vein. The decision to do this must be after discussion with a senior member of the PiCC and VA team due to potential for increased risk of thrombus.
Insertion site infection

Insertion site inflammation is poorly predictive of catheter related blood-stream infections (CRBSI's). This is because most CRBSI's are due to intraluminal infections, and some bacteria (e.g. coagulase-negative staphylocci) cause little/no inflammation. Purulent exudate at an exit site, whilst uncommon, is highly predictive for infection and may necessitate removal. (See Troubleshooting Management Flow Chart 6 in appendix)
Pain

Pain in the shoulder, chest or neck may be due to PiCC malposition, extravasation (e.g. damaged PiCC) or thrombosis. A chest X-ray or lineogram will identify malposition and extravasation. (See Troubleshooting Management flow chart 2 to assess for thrombosis in appendix).
Difficult Removal

Gentle traction is all that is usually required to remove a PiCC Excessive force/stretching of line risks catheter fracture. The commonest cause is venospasm. Other potential factors include thrombus and fibrin strand formation.
Management:
Try repositioning the arm and re-applying gentle traction.
Apply a warm compress to the upper limb for 20-30 minutes. Consider re attempting this step in  hours if unable to remove PiCC.
If a fibrin strand/cap is a possibility, instil 2mg units of Alteplase within the catheter for one hour (see withdrawal occlusion section).
If the above are unsuccessful, contact Interventional Radiology for assistance.
If the catheter breaks during attempted removal:
If still visible from exit site then apply a clamp to the catheter and call for assistance. This will prevent air embolus.
If not visible, place patient in the Trendelenburg position and call for urgent assistance. This will require Interventional Radiology or Vascular Surgery assistance.
Staff education training requirements

The PiCC and VA Service Team will endeavour to provide ad hoc ward PiCC and Mid-line Care and Maintenance training alongside regular training incorporated to Trust IV Therapy Training and Induction days for both medical and nursing staff.

All registered nurses are required to complete the trust CVC and PICC competencies prior to accessing and maintaining PICC's and short term CVC's. Ward sisters have a responsibility and accountability to ensure their staff are competent and adhere to those competencies.
The PICC and VA Team have and remain willing to provide teaching sessions when requested to all of the MDT both inside and outside of hospital setting where possible.
Transfer into the community setting
The trust discharge process should be followed when discharging a patient with a PiCC or Mid-Line in situ.

District Nurse Services referral will need to be completed and put into place ready for the patients' discharge for care and maintenance of these lines alongside administration of therapies if the patients are housebound only.
Hospital at Home patients will be accepted whilst in hospital. Refer to their SOP.

The PiCC Team should always be informed by email at mse.picc.line.broomfield@nhs.net or phone call (extension/answerphone 6154) of a patient's discharge with a line in situ to ensure follow-up and timely line removal when appropriate and to ask any advice required and the team will answer any patient and team enquiries.
District Nurses can remove Mid and PiCC lines in the community in the same way they remove peripheral cannulae and also ‘Securacath'
Patients will need to re-visit the PiCC Service or Day Therapy team removal if they are considered to be a high risk of bleeding due to full anti-coagulation
Documentation

The following details must be documented in the patient's medical notes or EPR with regards to troubleshooting by a doctor or PiCC Team Member and relevant details of the ongoing care and maintenance and or treatment of complications (in the patients nursing notes if performed by a nurse).
Healthcare professional who performed the maintenance or troubleshooting

The length of the line exposed at the insertion site compared to that documented at insertion now, observations related to insertion site and related bleeding, swelling, inflammation, ability to aspirate blood to confirm position, able to flush all lumens easily and any pain or other symptoms upon flushing or administration of treatment
Time and date of maintenance and VIP score on Trust Saving Lives Tool/Vital pac – CVC observations to be completed by registered nurses only.
Time and date of first noted difficulty with the line and date/time currently, actions taken and subsequent results and plan for the patient and their line.
If out of PiCC Service hours an e-mail or message left on extension 6154 for the PiCC Service team to follow-up upon their return with name, date and time.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Frequency of the monitoring e activity
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Numbers of lines inserted, infections, line related Deep Venous Thrombus
Audit/live database run by PICC and VA service

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the PICC and Vascular Access Lead, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform also those involved of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary equality analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 12)

Appendix 9: Peripherally inserted central catheter (PiCC) related deep vein thrombus (DVT) treatment algorithm
Risk Factors:
Active carcinoma or cancer treatment
Age > 60 years
Dehydration
Obesity (BMI > 30kg/m2)
One or more significant co-morbidities: HD; metabolic/endocrine/respiratory conditions; acute infection diseases; inflammatory conditions
Personal history or first degree relative with history of VTE
Use of Oestrogen/containing contraceptive treatment
Varicose veins with phlebitis
Suggestive Signs and Symptoms:
Swelling of limb/shoulder/neck ± pain
Visible difference in colour of limb i.e. appears darker/blue hue
Limb temperature cooler than opposite
Engorgement of veins of affected limb/potentially, neck vein involvement
Page  of

Appendix11: Competency for the management of central venous access device (CVAD)
Name  Ward
This competency document is designed to be used in conjunction with
The generic core competency document
Aseptic Technique and Aseptic Non-Touch Technique Policy
Prevention of Intravenous Device related infections

Completion of this documentation can be used as practice related feedback as part of revalidation. All registered nurses accessing and caring for Short Term Central Venous Catheters and Peripherally Inserted Central Catheters (PICC) should have completed these successfully. Ward sisters have the responsibility to ensure this is completed by relevant staff.

table_items.text: Care of the Central Venous Access Device
Date of initial self/ mentor assessment
Understands the indications for a Central Venous Access Device (CVAD)
Understands the differences between tunnelled and non-tunnelled CVAD's, can identify the different types and their uses
Able to refer a patient to appropriate specialist services i.e. PICC team

data.text: Page  of

table_items.text: 'Strict Surgical Approach Asepsis' is also to be implemented in all care of all PiCC's in MiD as per guideline/policy
Able to safely aspirate and flush a CVAD in accordance with the type of CVAD and appropriate guidelines
Able to ‘troubleshoot' CVAD and know when to obtain further help and who to contact
Able to identify complications as a result of the CVAD and refer appropriately
Able to safely administer medications via a CVAD, both as a bolus and via an infusion pump
Able to change specific CVAD dressings incorporating securement devices and chlorhexidine impregnated sponges where required and in accordance with epic-3 IP guidelines.
Can identify which CVADs can be removed without surgical intervention
Can safely remove the ‘Securacath' securement device prior to removal of PiCC/Midline
Able to safely remove a CVAD, understands the risks and potential complications
Able to explain the procedure for discharge of a patient with a Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter (PICC) line

data.text: Page  of
Peripherally inserted central catheter (PiCC) management/14019 /2.03
Peripherally inserted central catheter (PiCC) management/14019 /2.03
Appendix 12: PICC damage
PiCC Damage
Internal damage  External damage
(fractured etc)  (Accidental cut etc)
Stop all infusions
Place patient on the left side and minimize movement of involved limb
If suspected catheter embolism call immediately for emergency medical assistance and follow ILS algorithm
Label the damage line “DO NOT USE”
Contact vascular surgeons and /or interventional radiologists
Interventional /surgical procedure is likely required
Clamp the line between the exit site and the damaged area or fold the external segment and secure
Wrap a piece of occlusive dressing around the break to ensure that the line doesn't get contaminated
Label the damage line “ DO NOT USE”
Contact PICC service during service hours otherwise vascular surgeons
Page  of

Addition of algorithm for incidence of fracture or damage to line

To improve patient care and safety
